title: One of the most compelling dramas of the downtrodden
content: Wow! Approaching Potemkin isn't easy because a lot of debris has accumulated in so much criticism and analysis that much like Citizen Kane one can wonder whether anyone actually watches this movie today or simply talks about it based on rumors. The movie's greatness doesn't lie only in the overwhelming montage technique, much more compelling in Eisenstein's earlier feature, Stachka. Potemkin is one of the best movies of the twenties because the technical brilliance present in Stachka has been completely assimilated by the director who now uses that technique proficiently not in an obtrusive way. From this perspective this movie looks more like The Magnificent Ambersons as compared to Kane. The technique in Potemkin is much more directed to achieving a certain artistic goal instead of simple bravado as it was the case with many shots from Stachka. In the latter movie we have some up-side down shots with mirrors that have little significance in the whole movie. In Potemkin every shot has a meaning in the larger frame of the whole film. The fact that Eisenstein controlled and perfectly balanced all the constitutive elements of his movie is what entitles him to the title of great director. He was much more than the improver of montage theory which he understood here and in the later Alexander Nevsky to function in a more subtle manner, very modern at that in the sense that the viewer should not be conscious that the cinema is "playing tricks". At its best Potemkin manages to draw the viewer in the medium so much that its "lesson" is much more compelling on an emotional level than that in Stachka. Take for instance the idea of child slaughtering. In Stachka we have a soldier dropping a child from a height. In Potemkin we have much more subtle technique where we are forced to feel the drama by placing ourselves in the same position as the tumbling unfaltering cart with the child in it. This is a technique striving for dramatic realism and it is much more compelling than a simple montage. It is an example of many dramatic shots that remain very fresh on a very emotional level until today.That Potemkin is a very modern movie is obvious from the way the soundtrack serves the images; I am talking about the original Shostakovich soundtrack. One of the most compelling and dramatic shots of the film is the montage at the beginning with the images of breaking waves perfectly juxtaposed with the music in a very expressionist manner almost like a shout of outrage.Much more than Stachka this movie shows us not only a developed collective character but the individual is much more obvious. The heroic element concentrated in a person as in Nevsky is not yet here but Potemkin shows some of the ideas that will eventually mark a break between Eisenstein and his Soviet patrons. Class struggle does not have the same humorous touch we see in Stachka, Potemkin has a more dramatic edge and I cannot remember a moment when I could laugh. This may be because the director understood that this film has a much deeper impact on the viewer with the Odessa steps episode for instance so any humor could have been damaging.For what I know the cut I saw, something near 74 minutes is not the "original cut". I have no idea what the alleged cut material consisted in but I cannot imagine this movie being more complete than it already is. And the ending, rather anticlimactic is not as some have said flawed but actually very compelling. Eisenstein's idea was that the Revolution is something, as Lenin states in the motto at the beginning, fair and legitimate so that everyone will "see the light" and take the right decision when it comes to it. The fact that the other ships join the mutineers is something natural seeing as they were in the same "tight spot" under the tsarist regime.And as a final comment: take the "propaganda" from this movie i.e. Lenin's motto and you get one of the most humane cries for freedom ever depicted in a film. What else is Potemkin if not a beautiful portrayal of man's endless and passionate struggle to escape slavery? I have always been impressed that unlike Riefenstahl's "documentaries" Eisenstein can be very easily dissociated from the Communist doctrine in a variant of which he deeply believed. As an artist he had such an integrity that he strived to put on screen what he believed was right. Up to some point he thought that his artistic ideals coincided with the Party doctrine. That he understood his art as serving a social purpose is something worth respecting, he wanted to change the world through art, to make people better. History has proved Eisenstein and his kin were fools whose ideals have been thwarted by the most abject interests of the Party. But there is no doubt at least for me that as a true artist (that is more than a technical wizard) Eisenstein was honest, much more so than his American counterpart Griffith. Both Griffith and Eisenstein need to be placed in their culture to assimilate their message today. It is not their fault that history proved them wrong, it is a simple fact of life.

title: Mutiny on a Russian battleship 1905 with consequences both tragic and heroic
content: Of course it is still impressing after almost a hundred years, for its amazing sense of details, its tremendously dramatic impact, its highly strung pathos and its wonderful cinematography all through, but still there is room for some objections. It can't be helped, but it is tendentious, it glories in Soviet nationalism with the individual being effaced in the movement of the masses, it even says so in the text, and it is somewhat hysterical in its constant muddle of crowds amassing and running together in fanatic frenzy, which reminds me of the fanatic Christians massing together to massacre the poor Hypatia in the Agora film. It's a film about crowds for the masses, where individualism is completely run over and abolished, which it can't be for human reasons. It's a great film but with tendencies that must bring misgivings, as a prelude to the age of totalitarianism under Stalin and others.

title: Propaganda at its best
content: N. F. Agadzhanova-Shutko wrote Battleship Potemkin's script not only as a revolutionary propaganda film, but also as a vehicle for Sergei Eisenstein's testing of his theories of montage. Eisenstein then edited the film in such a way as to generate the utmost emotional reaction, so that the viewer would feel empathy and compassion for the defiant sailors and extreme dislike for their pitiless overlords. In the style of most propaganda, the characterization is clear-cut and uncomplicated, so that the audience can unmistakably tell with whom they should identify. The point is, Eisenstein's theory of montage has been diluted and adulterated since then to the point where it's either completely ignored or thought of as kindergarten know-how. Film-making has now evolved quite a lot for the Battleship to have any kind of strong effect on us, non-contemporary. The dialogue in the inter-titles feels painfully scripted. The cards that don't represent dialogue are so self-explanatory that they make the images futile and redundant: "Bowl of soup" (wow). One shot juxtaposed with another doesn't necessarily say it all. One has to direct the forces within a shot for a cut to serve any purpose. The picture's legendary moment is, of course, the scene of the slaughter of civilians on the Odessa Steps, in which soldiers shoot a mother who is pushing a baby in a carriage, and it rolls down the steps in the midst of the escaping mass. And this image has since been imitated in The Untouchables, Brazil, The Godfather, just to name a few. Anyway, it's important to note that the genius of the director surpassed the original quality of the script, building a classic.

title: A Timeless Testament to Cinematic Power and Historical Fervor
content: "Battleship Potemkin" stands as a monumental work in the history of cinema, not just for its technical and artistic innovations, but for its sheer emotional and ideological power. The film captivates with its stunning visuals, ranging from beautifully poetic scenes to some of the most iconic moments in film history. Its creative prowess is evident in every frame, showcasing groundbreaking techniques that have influenced generations of filmmakers.What truly sets "Battleship Potemkin" apart is its intense and fervent power. The film is a masterclass in building tension and emotion, greatly enhanced by its impactful soundtrack. Each scene is crafted to evoke a strong response, immersing the viewer in the tumultuous atmosphere of the narrative.Despite its status as a propaganda piece, the fervor and idealism portrayed in the film are deeply touching. It captures the essence of human aspiration and belief in a better future, making it resonate on a fundamental level. However, viewed through the lens of history, these ideals take on a poignant quality, reflecting the ephemeral nature of such revolutionary fervor and the ultimate disillusionment of grand human ideas.The film's propaganda aspect might be its only drawback for some, but even this contributes to its overall impact. "Battleship Potemkin" is more than a film; it's a historical artifact that encapsulates the spirit of its time, and the dreams and disappointments of a generation.In conclusion, nearly a century after its release, "Battleship Potemkin" remains a towering achievement in cinema. Its power, creativity, and emotional intensity make it not just a significant cultural and political statement, but also a timeless piece of cinematic art that continues to awe and inspire.

content: This 1925 film narrates the story of the mutiny on board battleship Potemkin at the port of Odessa. Following his montage theory, Eisenstein plays with scenes, their duration and the way they combine to emphasize his message, besides he uses different camera shot angles and revolutionary illumination techniques. The "Odessa Steps" sequence in Potemkin is one of the most famous in the history of cinema. title: Prepare yourselves for a mutiny...
content: *THIS REVIEW MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS... OR MAYBE NOT. THE WARNING IS THE SAME FOR ALL*The crew of the battleship Potemkin start a mutiny because of the low-life conditions in there. The meat they have to eat has worms, for Christ's sake! They take the ship, dispose of the high officials, and approach the nearest port. But Nicholas II has send his troops to mitigate the mutiny, at all costs.This masterpiece of the soundless cinema is, by far, one of the most influential movies ever. Not only it was a very efficient piece of propaganda, but it also has one of the most iconic scenes in film history.The objective Eisenstein pursued was to demonise the Czar's regime and to criticize the bad conditions of life on board the battleships. Achieving it, the movie helped influence countless others propaganda films. Even Joseph Goebbels himself admired it...It also has one of the most famous scenes in cinema: the Odessa steps. Watching the Czar's cossacks marching in line down the stairs shooting at the civilians not only touches us deep inside, but it has generated numerous homages (films like 'Brazil', 'Star Wars Episode III', 'The Untouchables', etc.) This is the kind of film film students MUST watch, just to learn the power that a good narration can have.

title: Perhaps the greatest silent film
content: Battleship Potemkin is a silent film by Sergei Eisenstein. It gives a historically dramatized account of the battleship Potemkin, where the crew revolts against the captains. This is Soviet propaganda without a doubt, which gives it an interesting historical perspective. It mainly focuses on the importance of revolution, brutality of the Tsar, and individual expense for the greater good. All these strong themes make the film easy to focus on, even for modern audiences.The acting is good, although not outstanding. The main captain, doctor, and priest make an infamous representation of cold leadership. The captains of the ship are contrasted with the crew by their black jacket. This makes it instantly recognizable which side is which. The placement of the people and actions is perfect. Its editing like this that makes it so easy to watch even though the film itself is old. The good planning carries out through the whole film.The most impressive quality is the cinematography. The shots of the water, ship, and building structures are all meticulously done. A very effective image is shown early on, where the ships meat is crawling with maggots. The captain's refusal to provide adequate food for the crew reaches a climax when he plans to execute crew members that did not like the soup. This leads to the first impressive scene: the ships revolt. The action here is comparable with many modern action flicks. Later, the famous scene on the Odessa steps and the conclusion are also shown through phenomenal editing. It is very obvious that this quality is years ahead of its time. Few films are so technically great without the use of color and sound.This might be the greatest silent film in existence. I have yet to see Metropolis, but have seen most other notable silent films. I found Battleship Potemkin to be the easiest to watch out of the bunch. That, along with historical and technical significance, makes this a must see for anyone that loves studying film.

title: A few thoughts on a widely regarded masterpiece
content: NOTE: This is not a conventional review; this is my required response to Sergei Eisenstein's Battleship Potemkin for my college course Intro to Film & Screen Studies...Cinema, both domestic and foreign, owes a lot to Sergei Eisenstein for creating not only one of the most successful propaganda films with Battleship Potemkin, but one of the most successful examples of montage in history. Eisenstein employs a wide variety of subversive montage styles here, some considered tonal ones that string together a continuous feeling that rubs off on an audience, some for the purpose of continuity and consistency in events, and some for the purpose of putting grandiose, large-scale sequences into a specified perspective, though all significant in their own right.One of the most jarring inclusions of structurally conflicting shots is the famous shot of the statue of the lion, which is shown sleeping, awakening, and rising all in the matter of about two seconds. These static images, when strung together, inspire the kind of momentary shock we, the audience, have upon watching Eisenstein concoct a film so raucous and battle-hungry that it's as if the lion is replicating our personal feelings whilst watching the film. The conflict established is more or less a circumstance of reactionary response to the disobedience of order; order which is constantly affirmed throughout the entire first chapter of the film.Then there's the scene in the second chapter where the passengers aboard Potemkin begin to rebel. Eisenstein utilizes his montage theory to establish the events occurring before zeroing in on specific people fighting and specific blows in a way that shows the conflict between the two parties whilst showing a more concise focus on a large-scale playing field. The effect is unique because it's rare we see a large battle (or even a large battle conducted in a small area) specified so humanly by way of close-ups and intimate shooting techniques that Eisenstein employs that make the sequence so personal.As far as alternative logic goes – where Eisenstein creates some sort of visual poetry or distinction without the use of his beloved montage technique – there's the scene early in the film where one of the captains goes to observe the actions in the bunkers. Eisenstein's camera observes the actions of the captain while interjecting cuts of pots and pans precariously placed atop boards of wood that are strung up and suspended to the room's ceiling. These scenes establish what the captain is looking at and what his environment is composed of in a manner that relates greatly to Kulesov and his own personal effect.Then there are scenes that are more concerned with fleshing out a specific event, rather than encapsulating the horror and the messiness of other events (the uprising aboard the Potemkin and the famous Odessa Steps sequence just to name a few). One scene is the final straw for the workers, of sorts, when they are persuaded to believe that rotting, maggot-ridden meat is okay for consumption, despite being viewed by everybody on board, even the cooks, as otherwise. Eisenstein keeps things grounded more-or-less in a real-time here, allowing his camera to go back and forth between the workers and the captains in a manner that doesn't shortchange or rapidly look for a way out of this event in order to interject other scenes and create a compilation of "last straws" for the workers. This scene in particular establishes the logic that Eisenstein uses can be equal parts broadly observant, as seen in his montages, or decidedly focused.In a way, I feel Battleship Potemkin was a film made for the masses to, for once, look introspectively at their situations in Russian and observe the treacherous, unfair living conditions and the willfully oppressive nature of the rich and able. Eisenstein had to combat the fact that most of the commonwealth Russian population was illiterate and unknowing of their own exploitation, which made him make a film like this that, despite being able to be dissected in numerous ways, almost demands a response of any kind. The complete and total disregard for the health and wellbeing of humans should at least warrant some response from people, and Eisenstein's images reflect the horrors of oppression without getting lost in symbolism or any kind of discernible auteurism. His montage elements only add to a film, rather than being stylistic distractions that work to muddle the themes at hand.Starring: Aleksandr Antonov, Vladimir Barksy, and Grigori Aleksandrov. Directed by: Sergei Eisenstein.

title: visually powerful but hard to follow and disturbing scenes
content: Battleship Potemkin is often hailed as one of the greatest and most influential films of all time, especially for its use of montage and its powerful imagery. The Odessa Steps sequence, in particular, is an iconic moment in cinema history that set the stage for generations of filmmakers. While there's no denying its artistic impact, the film can be challenging for today's viewers.The story feels disjointed, and without a clear narrative thread or well-developed characters, it's tough to stay invested in what's happening. title: Groundbreaking...Influential...Powerful...Invented & Embellished Cinema Techniques
content: Many Things Today are Hampered by a "Paralysis From Analysis", in Our Age of Information.Film-Historians Recognize that Landmark Films such as "The Birth of a Nation" (1925)..."Battleship Potemkin" (1925)...and "Citizen Kane" (1941)...have, through the Decades, been put Under the Microscope and Usually are Seen as Exactly What They Are...Cinematic Icons of Groundbreaking, Influential, and Direction-Changing Events Examples of "Cinema as Art", Forever Changing the Art-Form into Something "New".This Silent Film, Produced by Communists for Propaganda Purposes, Resulted in Things Unanticipated, Concerning the Art of Motion Pictures.The Politics Actually became Secondary to the Impact of Sergio Eisenstein's Direction and Handling of the Film.Although the Politics did Cause the Movie to be Banned All Over the World well into the 1950's.But Film Schools were More Enamored by the "Montage", the Cinematography, and Most Importantly the Use of Editing to Cause Emotional Reactions from the Audience.After All...Politics Change...but Art Remains Art.The Famous Scene of Slaughter on the "Odessa Steps" is so Powerful to Witness, even Today, that one can See that it Immediately and Instantly Changed the Way Movies were Made.If one was to Sight a Modern Equivalent of the Influence and Impact...it could Possibly be Sam Peckinpah's "The Wild Bunch" (1969) with the Finale of Slow-Motion Carnage, Blood-Letting, and Hyper-Editing that Changed the Face of Film Permanently.Even Compared to Peckinpah's Film, which at the Time had more Edits than Any Film in History, Eisenstein's "Odessa Steps" Sequence Still Packs a Visceral Punch.A Testament to its Transcendence of Time, as it was Most Definitely way "Ahead of its Time".One of Cinema's Milestone's and for the Film-Buff, Critic, or Historian, it's a...Must SeeFor All Others, it's...Worth a Watch.

title: "Battleship Potemkin": A Monumental Achievement in Soviet Silent Film
content: "Battleship Potemkin," directed by Sergei Eisenstein and released in 1925, is a landmark film in the history of Soviet silent cinema, and deserves a strong 9/10 rating. This film tells the story of the mutiny on the titular battleship, which took place in 1905 during the Russian Revolution. Through a series of powerful and unforgettable images, Eisenstein tells the story of the sailors' struggle for freedom and dignity against the oppressive forces of the tsarist regime.One of the film's most notable achievements is its innovative use of montage. Eisenstein's editing style, which he called "intellectual montage," was a groundbreaking approach that used a rapid-fire series of shots to convey complex ideas and emotions. In "Battleship Potemkin," Eisenstein uses montage to create a sense of immediacy and urgency, bringing the viewer right into the heart of the action.The film's cinematography is equally impressive. Shot by cinematographer Eduard Tisse, the film's images are visually stunning, with a bold use of light and shadow that heightens the drama and adds to the film's already-powerful atmosphere. The film's mise-en-scène, or overall visual design, is equally impressive, with the film's sets and costumes helping to create a vivid and memorable world that feels both otherworldly and real.The film's soundtrack, composed by Edmund Meisel, is also noteworthy, with a powerful and sweeping score that heightens the film's already-intense atmosphere. The film's use of sound, in general, is noteworthy, with the film's diegetic and non-diegetic sound used to great effect to create a sense of immediacy and to bring the film's world to life.Another standout aspect of the film is its thematic depth. At its core, "Battleship Potemkin" is a film about the power of the collective, and the importance of standing up for one's beliefs. The film's depiction of the sailors' struggle against the tsarist regime is both inspiring and powerful, speaking to the human desire for freedom and dignity. These themes are woven into the fabric of the film in a way that makes the film's story all the more impactful, lending the film a depth that many films of its era lack.In conclusion, "Battleship Potemkin" is a masterpiece of Soviet silent cinema, a film that remains as relevant and powerful today as it was nearly a century ago. From its innovative use of montage to its visually stunning cinematography and its rich thematic depth, "Battleship Potemkin" is a film that truly deserves its place in the pantheon of great films. If you're a fan of classic cinema, Soviet film, or just great filmmaking in general, "Battleship Potemkin" is a must-see. I give it a strong 9/10 rating, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a visually stunning and emotionally powerful cinematic experience.

title: A classic even if it is propaganda
content: Battleship Potyomkin, a silent film from the early days of the Soviet Union. Made as a propaganda piece, it lives up to that intention but is still a great work of art. The director Eisenstein was only in his late twenties and went on to have a short but successful career.I watched the film on Youtube with English subtitles. This was thanks to the German Film Library Museum of Film and Television. It is a (very) dramatised version of the mutiny on board the battleship Potyomkin. The named characters were all real people from that event, part of the 1905 Russian Revolution. Sweeping reforms were won but many, including Lenin himself, later saw it as a rehearsal for the revolutions of 1917.Whilst watching it is a rewarding experience, it does have a few problems. The film can be repetitive at times and the propagandistic intent simplifies things. One thing to note is that the film has a few splashes of colour towards the end - a red flag that was flown on the ship.A couple of final notes. The Potyomkin itself did not survive until 1925, it was scrapped a few years before. As for the real mutineers, the last survivor died in 1987 at either 102 or 104. If he had lived a few more years, he would have outlived the Soviet Union.Many silent films are now sadly lost to time, but we should be thankful that this one survived. It is propaganda, but it is also a classic film.

title: Still one of the most ironic and misunderstood movies of all time.
content: The title alone would probably tell most Russians that Battleship Potemkin is not what it seems, since in Russian a 'Potemkin village' is something which is not what it seems. In the 18th century, Marshal Potemkin tried to impress Catherine the Great with his supposed success in developing the Volga region by showing her new villages as she sailed down the river. The village buildings were just quickly erected facades with nothing behind them.But did Eisenstein have a choice about the name? Well, it could have been called 'Comrade Vakulinchuk'. Or '1905', without a battleship in sight (it's just a movie made for 20th anniversary of the somewhat abortive 1905 Revolution).Or it could have been called 'Kronstadt 1921'. In 1921, the sailors at Kronstadt naval base outside Leningrad mutinied in protest at the harshness of the policy of War Communism, under the slogan 'Communism without the Bolsheviks'. The mutiny was suppressed by troops ironically led by an aristocrat, Marshal Tukhachevsky (later shot by Stalin in the Thirties). Eisenstein's diary records a lengthy meeting with Tukhachevsky around that time. However Lenin called Kronstadt the spark that lit up the situation, and abandoned War Communism in favor of the much milder New Economic Policy (NEP, 1921-1927). In 1925 Stalin was trying to consolidate his hold on power following Lenin's death the previous year, and he supported the NEP against its left-wing critics.So Eisenstein's leftist-beloved movie is ironically pro-Stalinist but anti-leftist propaganda, warning of the horrors that will return if Stalin is beaten, with the nasty aristocrat-led Cossacks on the Odessa steps in 1905 being allegorical stand-ins for the nasty aristocrat-led Bolshevik troops at Kronstadt in 1921.Of course that particular party line had to go out the window in 1927, when Stalin, having seen off his opponents, promptly adopted their policies and scrapped the NEP.It's strange how neither leftists nor rightists seem to notice any of this despite arguing over the movie for over 75 years.

title: Eisenstein montage is amazing.
content: Battleship Potemkin is one of the most influential films of all time. Serguei Eisenstein, the director and writer, is a genius and the way he uses montage is amazing. He creates suspense and emotion with shots like he had a supernatural power. To him, montage wasn't a device like it is used today in most of the movies. For him, it was a way to communicate with the audience in general. The Odessa Staircase sequence and the arrival of the ships at the harbor are great examples of this. The former shows the tragedy of the revolution and the latter, the passion. A curiosity about this picture is that it has 1346 shots. This is the double of the average of the movies at that time. This tells how much Sergei liked and trusted this theory.

title: To the revolution!
content: A group of marines had enough. Lead by a charming man, they decided to raise a mutiny against the corrupt leadership of their boat. They somewhat won, but the fight leaves their leader dead. When his body is left in the pier, a group of equally disenchanted masses develop a sense of mutiny themselves only to be crushed by the same military the boatmen tried to overthrow. All hell breaks loose AND the mutiny goes on.Their is a moment in filmmaking when Battleship Potemkin is highly parodies/homage AND I could definitely see why. It is something that just wants you to go up and do something. Its high propaganda THAT does feel relevant, more so after it was made.Eisenstein's style here is just amazing. Every little thing in this film works marvelously. His earlier film of the same year, Strike already has showings of greatness BUT this is where I think it just is developed fully. The story, the actions, the sequences. Its much more pointed and carefully paced. Even his extravagant style from Strike is somewhat subdued here until the climaxes. Its no wonder that this film was voted on top ten of the BFI list for almost six decades until another Russian Montage film (A Man with a Moving Camera) replaced it.Its just so modern and relevant. AND even with the number of parodies, it still feels fresh, which is a testament of Eisenstein's style and storytelling.Highly recommended.

title: Down with the Tsarist Oppression
content: This is Eisenstein taking everything he'd pushed the envelope stylistically on in Strike and applying it in a more streamlined fashion. A stripped down version of a much larger project that was going to include a huge history of the 1905 Revolution, Eisenstein, convinced he didn't have enough time, focused on one episode, the rebellion of the sailors on the eponymous battleship. And it works...extremely well. This is something of a marvel of silent filmmaking. It's exciting, tight at only 70 minutes, and surprisingly involving considering Eisenstein's continued insistence on making a film of the masses without individuals (he bends that rule a bit here).The titular ship, Potemkin, rests in the Odessa harbor with a brewing mutiny. The one person in this whole film with any real delineation is Grigory Vakulinchuk (Aleksandr Antonov), the leader of the group of men who object to being fed meat covered in maggots. It's a powder keg as the haughty commanding officer, the cruel NCO, and the rest of the command lord over the common men who make up the sailing crew. When the crew ends up refusing to eat the meat, led by Vakulinchuk, they are ordered to be put to death which initiates the mutiny.The frustration I found in Strike had a lot to do with the lack of a terribly strong throughline. That was in no small part because there were no characters, just masses and caricatures (on the bad side). Here, enough time is spent with Vakulinchuk that his presence, though cut off at about the halfway point, ends up driving the action through the rest of the film. He gets killed in the mutiny, and then he becomes a martyr to the cause, the people of Odessa filing past his dead body in a tent when the victorious sailors come to shore. He's an inspiration to the people in Odessa, already hearing news of revolution from other parts of Russia, and they coalesce around the sailors of the Potemkin.The film is obviously its most exciting in its final two parts out of five when we see the iconic Odessa Steps sequence and then the final confrontation with another Tsarist naval vessel. This is where Eisenstein's cinematic techniques take their fullest form, telling a story of complex events in tiny pieces stitched together without ever making the action incoherent. There's this flow of information from the images chosen in the order chosen to create a large picture from small pieces. Eisenstein works to create a large montage of images about a large group of people, and it works really well. The focus is on the action of the Tsarist forces massacring groups of innocents who only wish to be free, and it's all guns, marching, babies, and carriages as the people face the wrath of their Tsar for daring to want good meat.The Odessa Steps sequence gets all the praise, but I actually think the faceoff with the other Tsarist naval vessel by the Potemkin crew is more impressive. It's essentially built out of nothing, Eisenstein obviously not able to get footage of two battleships chasing each other in any way (there are some shots of multiple craft, but nothing that could be considered a faceoff in any way), and the montage ends up being created by the cutting of wakes from the ship, moving engine parts, and concerned faces on crew. Combined with the score by Edmund Meisel (to be played by pianists during the showing of the film), and it's an exciting bit of suspense built out of essentially nothing. I find that quite impressive.Really, this is a gem of a movie. It's exciting and thrilling with enough of an actual emotional core to make all of the action work with some impact. This is Eisenstein compromising his original approach to cinematic language by embracing the individual character just enough to provide his actual main character, the mass of Russians, a reason for their revolution. It personalizes the conflict in a way necessary for the film to work dramatically. It's still thin propaganda, but it's great, thin propaganda. It invites the audience to feel the emotional connection to those heroes, 20 years prior, who fell at the dastardly hand of the Tsarist forces. It works, and it works really, really well.

title: Propaganda Made Watchable
content: Based on the 1905 mutiny on the ship bearing the title's name, "Battleship Potemkin" is an energetic and highly active account of the uprising and the events that followed. Featuring the events inside the ship which led to the rebellion and what transpired with the crew afterwards the film is one moving narrative of constant action highlighted by the brisk herky-jerky motion of cinema during the time. A taut and bracing script, constantly functioning machinery, humanity in motion - the movie stirs to bigger life in the famous Odessa steps scene where one can still feel the tension and chill of the tragedy as it unfolds. Ironically, with all the activities mentioned the film is snagged by slow parts throughout which highlights the movies lack of depth and shows that a movie has to have more than action to leave a truly profound impact. Famed director Sergei Eisenstein's most well known flick and one of the more successful propaganda efforts made, this overrated product of its time is still one of the more watchable silents to hold up well.

title: Astonishing!

title: Worthy to a History Buff
content: Like Citizen Kane, this is an IMPORTANT film in the development of cinema. Both of these films usually show up in the "Top Ten Films of all time lists" and herein lies the confusion. What are the criteria? For modern sophisticated film viewers both films are laughable, but for film history buffs they are worthy films for their breaking of new ground: BP for its use of montage, and CK for its long shots and nonlinear plotting. Modern audiences have seen it all before. Being first is not necessarily equated with being the best, and subsequent films have probably managed to beat these two at their own game. Memento springs to mind as a worthy successor to CK. It doesn't matter if you liked it. It only matters that it did it first.Reception is all

title: Finally The Definitive Restoration Of This World Cinema Classic.
content: It's hard to think of a more important silent film or any major work of world cinema that has taken as long to be issued in a definitive version than BATTLESHIP POTEMKIN. It took many years and the combined efforts of several different film archives to put POTEMKIN back together again but it has been worth the wait for now it is possible to finally see the most influential movie ever made the way it's creator Sergei Eisenstein intended.Ever since the premiere at the Bolshoi Theatre in 1925, POTEMKIN has been subject to censorship in one form or another. Not only was the film cut but the original score by German composer Edmund Meisel was discarded after the film's initial run and this had a huge impact as we can now see and hear in this restoration. The images will always retain their power but they are doubly enhanced by Meisel's propulsive driving score which sounds like Shostakovich who was 19 at the time and must have been influenced by what he heard here. It's ironic that for the film's 50th anniversary (the version most readily available until now) the music of Shostakovich provided the background and the film was cut to fit the music. All of this is covered in the excellent documentary TRACING BATTLESHIP POTEMKIN that comes with this 2 DVD set.As for the movie itself, it has never looked this good. Images are sharp and clear, the contrast of the black and white photography is excellent and the colorization of the raising of the red flag has been restored. Most important of all is the return of the edited material which changes the look and feel of certain scenes. The famous "Odessa Steps" sequence is longer, has different points of view, and is more violent than before. The recording of the original score is top notch and, as I said earlier, adds immeasureably to the total film experience. Overall this is a truly astonishing set and one no lover of world cinema should be without.My only complaint, and it's a minor one, is that I wish they had included the 1976 50th anniversary edition as the second disc (instead of the new version with Russian title cards) so that we could see the differences between the two and could note the changes made to bring BATTLESHIP POTEMKIN back to Eisenstein's vision...For more reviews visit The Capsule Critic.

title: Grotesque and captivating
content: Sergei Einstein's silent film, Bronenosets Potyomkin, captures real life events from 1905. It's been named as one of the most influential propaganda films of all time. I don't exactly agree with this, but I do think that Einstein did a wonderful job at showing us the injustice and brutality of actual events. One of the scenes that stood out to me was when the crew was fed rotten, maggot infested meat. I was extremely disgusted by this scene, but thought Einstein did an excellent job at showing us what their life was like aboard the ship, even though it might have been dramatized. There were a number of vivid and grotesque images that stayed in my mind even after I watched it. The Odessa Steps was one of the most violent scenes that I have seen. Einstein did a fabulous job at creating shots that were rapid and sharp. It enhanced the feeling of panic as the civilians run down the stairs. The close-ups used by Einstein of the panicked civilians really captured our class' attention as we gasped and cringed. I believe that the use of these zoom shots added to the drama and emotion of the audiences. In the beginning of this scene he zooms out and captures the full flight of stairs and the mass amounts of helpless civilians. This caused me to feel a sense of panic as I watched this scene due to his shot of the larger picture. As a propaganda film, Einstein did a wonderful job at making us feel sorry for these sailors. Although, this movie wasn't my favorite, I do think that Einstein created a action-packed silent film that had us at the edge of our seats. He did a wonderful job at grabbing our attention even though there was no sound.

title: Interesting look at a classic
content: I'll be the first to admit that film is not my expertise, and many of the nuances in Eisenstein's masterpiece may have been lost on me. It is clear that his control of the camera is impressive, and the way in which he creates emotion through the camera is equally as impressive. However, the story seemed a little contrived to me. Although the underlying event was fact, it seemed to intentionally incite emotion rather than draw it out naturally. In the scene at the steps, this behavior is prevalent. The chaotic stitching of shots together insights the desired emotion, but it ignores the fact that the actual event was much more benign than Eisenstein's reenactment. So, if we wan't a realist reenactment of Soviet Russia during this time period, I would recommend looking somewhere else; however, if you want to see one of the greatest innovators in film history, this is a great film to start. Eisenstein's most notable work was definitely in montage. This film allows us to see how these ideas were invented. Since the concept was unpolished at this point, it allows us to see Eisenstein's intent in creating effects through montage.If your looking for a casual day at the movies, this is not your pick. If you are a scholar of film, then there are a number of interesting points of exploration in terms of composition and exploration in film and narrative techniques. In this aspect, Eisenstein was a true pioneer.I know that was kind of a continued rant on just one aspect of the film, but it most certainly is a defining featuring. In addition, the film doesn't entertain on some level. The action is interesting and does help to see the discontent manifested under Russian Fascism. The plot plays very basic, and barely held my interest. The authorship is almost peripheral to what makes this interesting though.

title: An important piece of cinema-history
content: "Battleship Potemkin" is a silent movie made in the Soviet-Union in 1925 by master-director Sergej Eisenstein. This powerful movie remains after almost 80 years a landmark in cinema-history.  The movie tells the story of the crew on-board Battleship Potemkin during the revolution of 1905 after Russia had lost the war against Japan. On one side this is pure communist propaganda, on the other side this is probably one of the most powerful movies ever created. I saw this movie myself last year after my university teacher in Russian history recommended it to me.  Powerful imagery is the main element that you will remember after seeing this movie, especially the scene where people are slaughtered at the steps of Odessa in the Ukraine. See it.

title: One Of The First Films To Unlock The Power Of Cinema
content: A five-act story of a rebellion that sparked a revolution, Battleship Potemkin is a masterpiece of silent cinema that simply refuses to age. Often counted amongst the greatest films of all time, the film not only lives up to its mythical reputation but can still profoundly influence its viewers with its powerfully haunting images.Co-written & directed by Sergei Eisenstein, the film's five-act structure features a simple plot that appears straightforward on paper but gains enormous firepower once it goes through the cinematic treatment, thanks to the narrative techniques that Eisenstein experiments with and in process ends up adding a vital chapter to the storytelling manual.For a film of its time, Battleship Potemkin is shockingly violent and that Odessa Steps sequence is truly an all-timer, one that will effortlessly manage to surpass your highest expectations. The last act is just as impressive, benefiting from the perfect harmony attained together by the film's impeccable editing, immaculate camerawork & surging score.Overall, whether you consider it a propaganda piece or a historical account or an enduring portrait of the revolutionary spirit, Battleship Potemkin comes out as a winner on all fronts, and is an astounding achievement of its genre. Immortal for its contribution to cinema, and one of the first films to unlock the art form's true potential, this Soviet classic is essential viewing.

title: Movie Odyssey Review #014.1
content: #014.1 - Battleship Potemkin (1925) - released in Russia 12/21/25; viewed previouslyDOUG: I'd like to say a quick word about this Eisenstein film which we watched in Film Expression class, and were shown it again more recently in our History of Silent Film class (I slept through most of it, as I did with nearly every film we watched in that class, no matter how good). Eisenstein was, of course, a pioneer of film montage, and this film contains one of his best sequences, the famous 'Odessa Steps' sequence which follows a baby carriage rolling down the stairs followed by the oppressive Tsarist soldiers. The subject of Soviet Montage is always a key topic in any Film History class, and while it was important, a lot of my classmates have come to hate it, and feel scarred from being subjected to this and other Eistenstein films (a friend of mine jokingly called Soviet Montage "Throwing a bunch of random scenes together and calling it a film.") We decided we didn't need to re-watch this film for our Odyssey, since we would just be waiting for the Steps scene, and we've got plenty more Eisenstein to look forward to.KEVIN: I watched Sergei Eisenstein's seminal masterpiece Potemkin freshmen year in college in our Development of Film Expression class. Eisenstein's films are certainly not for the squeamish. It wasn't ever enough for him just to get across what happened. He seemed to want the viewer to be completely immersed in the action and the drama, and he achieved this through an unparalleled use of camera-work, editing, and harrowing depictions of the most graphic imagery ever captured on film for years after. None of his films demonstrate his style as perfectly as Potemkin. It's been years since I watched this film, and most of it I've forgotten, except of course the unforgettable Odessa Steps sequence, which is often regarded as Eisenstein's crowning achievement of film-making. I watched it yet again in another film class, and I managed to sleep through most of it, waking up just in time to see the Odessa Steps. What I stayed awake for I still managed to forget.Last film chronologically: The Big Parade (1925). Next film chronologically: The Black Pirate (1926).

title: not watching a movie but assessing history
content: It has no doubt been years, maybe decades, since anyone came to this movie cold. Film buffs, film school students and historians are obliged to view it, compelled to tick it off on their Viewing List so they can talk about the evolution of varying shot size, juxtaposition, and the Odessa Steps sequence. In fact, my Viewing List recommended watching the Odessa Steps sequence only.An attempt to access the film in terms of empathy for characters, emotional catharsis, or intellectual stimulation, is fraught with difficulty. The film is silent, foreign, ancient and propagandist. Yes, the shot flow, when analysed, reveals significant steps in the evolution of cinema narrative. However, The Boneshaker Bicycle was an important step in the development of bikes, but I wouldn't want to ride one. BP no doubt thrilled its contemporary audience, and film theorists can tell us why it is important. Personally, it just felt too far away in time for me to embrace it.An important film, yes; but not a wonderful one.

title: The best silent film. Ever
content: Battleship Potemkin was given the hidden compliment of being banned from release within the UK until 1950, but it was still known for it's revolutionary editing technique, offering montage to new editors. Quite simply, it follows the heroes of the film in a way in which is still quite unique today.The rebels are the good guys, and they fight the Czar with such audacity, and the film makes them rise as heroes, and there are so many symbols and metaphors within the film it is hard to believe it was made in the 1920's.The Odessa stairs sequence must be one of the most well known parts of cinema history, but to truly appreciate it you must see it. Eisenstein's genius was well worked, and aside from political points, I would recommend it to any fan of the history of film and it's evolution.

title: One of the All-Time Great Directors
content: What would Eisenstein do today!  His films still pack tremendous wallop even 65 years later.  Yes, the baby carriage falling down the steps and the bullet in the eye still impact today, but the most telling image is the lock-step soldiers with rifles and bayonets at the ready, treading forcefully down the steps is an even greater image! Eisenstein's films are masterworks of double entendre for just as he silently condemns the czarist authorities, the irony that he portrays is that the communists are just as guilty.  I believe that his films deliberately show this irony as his way of damning all authoritarian/totalitarian regimes, and he got away with this in the USSR by doing precisely this. The characters in his films are not first-rate actors, but the images and faces of these characters are startling in their realism.  Watch the monk playing the organ in "Alexander Nevsky" and you'll see what I mean. What a face!  And Eisenstein...what an artist of the first rank!
